awd_titl_txt: ECA-PGR: Under the Hood: The Genetic Components of Maize Transformation
awd_abstract_narration:
Maize (corn) is a staple crop in the US and worldwide, and serves as an important model for fundamental research. Maize production has experienced dramatic yield increases over the last century but faces challenges for further increases, particularly under highly variable climates and disease pressures. Revolutionary genome engineering tools (genome editing) offer great opportunities for improved understanding of the relationship between genetic information and traits, and for modifying genetic features for trait improvements. Unfortunately, most crop plants, including maize, are not readily amenable to plant tissue culture, thereby limiting the benefit from direct applications of genome editing tools. In this project, the genome of a maize line amenable to culture will be sequenced to facilitate the identification of the genetic elements that regulate culturability. Novel approaches will be developed for genetic decoding on the complex maize genome. In particular, a designable bacterial system specifically interacting with genes of interest in the maize genome will be utilized to study gene function and manipulate cell development. The project will also provide training for undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students in both genetics and computation, with an emphasis on large data education. In addition, the project will collaborate with the Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation to encourage involvement of historically underrepresented students in STEM fields.

Maize is the highest agronomically valued crop in the US. Genome engineering tools, including TALENs and CRISPRs, provide great potential for the elucidation of maize gene functions and trait improvements.  However, current genetic and genomic resources as well as transformation capacity in maize are insufficient for the full utilization of genome engineering tools. This project provides public resources that include a high-quality genome assembly of a highly transformation amenable maize inbred line, A188, and 150 doubled haploid (DH) lines from a cross of A188 with B73, a transformation recalcitrant inbred variety and the maize reference genome. Bulked RNA sequencing based mapping will be used for genetic mapping of traits related to embryogenesis and regeneration. Furthermore, the project will generate time-series transcriptome profiles from callus cells that are transiently expressing designer Transcription Activator-Like effectors (dTALes) of a known regulator of embryogenesis and regeneration.  These profiles will be used to construct multilayered hierarchical gene regulatory networks to identify high hierarchical regulators and hub genes that govern maize embryogenesis and regeneration. Ectopic gene expression and CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing will be used to validate select candidate genes. These genetic and genomic resources will advance genome engineering in a major crop species and improve understanding of the genetic basis of maize transformation and regeneration ability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Maize (Zea mays L.) is an important staple crop in the US and worldwide and serves as an excellent model for fundamental research. Maize production has experienced dramatic yield increases over the last century, while facing challenges for further increases due to climate uncertainty and disease pressures. Genome editing offers great opportunities for trait improvements. Unfortunately, most maize varieties are not readily amenable to regeneration, thus limiting the benefits from direct applications of genome editing tools. In this project, the genome of a regeneration-amenable maize line was sequenced with cutting-edge sequencing technologies. A high-quality maize genome has been constructed and publicly shared to facilitate gene editing studies. The genome has been compared with other maize genomes to correlate underlying DNA variations with differences in visible traits (e.g., seed and cob colors). During the process of genome assembly and comparisons, computational approaches were also developed to assess the quality of the genome assembly and to facilitate genome comparisons. The software packages are freely accessible through GitHub.

Using this regeneration-amenable maize variety in conjunction with a maize elite variety displaying poor regeneration traits, hundreds of recombinant inbred progenies were generated, from which the varieties with improved regeneration ability have been identified. The genomic regions controlling regeneration-related traits have been localized, and candidate genes for improved regeneration were prioritized through combining genetic analysis and gene regulatory network data. These identified genes are currently being verified and will be used for improving maize regeneration if the positive impact on regeneration is confirmed.

In addition, a bacterial protein delivery system was utilized to study gene function in maize. The bacterium was shown to be capable of protein delivery to host cells and, specifically, when DNA sequence-specific transcription factors were introduced, it exhibited the capability to regulate the expression of host genes. The system will be used to further dissect molecular mechanisms of various biological processes, including plant regeneration.

Developing a reliable maize regeneration system is pivotal for advancing biotechnology and ensuring long-term food security. This project has generated important genetic and genomic resources as well as innovative research tools, to dissect the genetic basis of plant regeneration. Additionally, the project offered training for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows in genetics, genomics, and computation with an emphasis on large data education. The project has involved Research & Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) students and historically underrepresented students from multiple programs such as the Kansas Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation and the Ronald E. McNair Post-Baccalaureate Achievement Program at University of Florida.

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2023
Modified by: Sanzhen Liu

Images (1 of )
  • Construction of tissue networks based on global gene expression. Gene expression data of diverse tissues were used for constructing tissue networks, which showed the similarity among tissues in term of their gene expression.
    Sanzhen Liu
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sanzhen Liu
    Networks of maize tissues
  • Genomic structural variation comparison showed both seed color and cob color are influenced by copy number variation of respective causal genes.
    Sanzhen Liu
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sanzhen Liu
    Maize inbred lines A188 and B73.
  • The bacterium was used to synthesize and deliver designer proteins to regulate gene expression in plant cells.
    Sanzhen Liu
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Sanzhen Liu
    Bacterium-mediated protein delivery in plant cells
